questions.text: USG done on a pregnant woman shows Spalding's sign. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spalding's sign:
    • Loss of alignment and overriding of the bones of the cranial vault due to shrinkage of the cerebrum after foetal death.
    • Early stage: Loss of alignment without overriding.
    • Develops earlier with vertex presentation than breech.
    • Detected within about 1 week after foetal death, but may take 2-3 weeks.
  • Maceration:
    • Aseptic autolysis of a dead fetus retained in the uterus, surrounded by amniotic fluid without air exposure.
    • Studied/classified by Langley.
    • Earliest signs (within 12 hours): Coppery-brown skin and skin slippage.
    • Blisters with serous or serosanguinous fluid appear for 24 hours.
    • Typical features by 3-4 days:
      • Sweetish, disagreeable odor.
      • Soft, flaccid body that flattens when placed on a flat surface.
      • Abnormal joint mobility.
      • Skull bones overriding each other (Spalding's sign).
      • Soft, edematous organs.
      • Body cavities contain reddish serous fluid.

Mummification of foetus (Option A):

  • Drying and preservation of dead fetus with shrunken, leathery skin due to absence of amniotic fluid and air exposure.
  • No Spalding's sign is seen.

Foetal macrosomia (Option B):

  • Condition where the fetus is significantly larger than average (>4,000 g).
  • Not associated with Spalding's sign or bone overriding.

Down's syndrome (Option C):

  • Genetic disorder characterized by trisomy 21.
  • No sonographic features like Spalding's sign.

Key Takeaways:

  • Spalding's sign is a sonographic indicator of foetal maceration.
  • Maceration occurs when a dead fetus remains in utero for days, leading to characteristic tissue changes.
  • This sign helps differentiate maceration from other fetal conditions like mummification or macrosomia.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is tested in Breslau's second life test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Breslau's second life test, also known as the stomach bowel test, evaluates the stomach and duodenum.
  • Purpose: To determine if the baby was born alive or stillborn.
  • Principle: A live-born child swallows some air during respiration; the presence of air in the stomach or duodenum indicates live birth.
  • Procedure:
    • The stomach and duodenum are removed with double ligatures tied at both ends.
    • The specimen is placed in water.
    • If it floats, a small cut is made underwater to check for escaping air bubbles.
    • Floating viscera releasing air bubbles when cut underwater indicates a positive test.

Lungs (Option A): Tested in the hydrostatic lung test, not Breslau's second life test.

Liver (Option C): Not involved in Breslau's life tests.

Heart (Option D): Not tested in Breslau's life tests.

Key Takeaways:

  • Breslau's second life test focuses on stomach and duodenum to detect air presence as evidence of live birth.
  • It is complementary to the hydrostatic lung test.
  • Test results can be affected by obstruction or decomposition.

questions.text: While doing the Raygat's test, an unrespired lung may float due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Raygat's test (also known as the floatation test, Breslau's first life test, or hydrostatic test) determines whether a newborn has respired.
  • Principle:
    • Specific gravity of lungs before respiration ≈ 1.050 (heavier than water → sinks).
    • Specific gravity after respiration ≈ 0.950 (presence of air → lighter than water → floats).
  • Method:
    • Remove lungs with bronchi, trachea, larynx; ligate.
    • Place lungs in water to observe floating or sinking.
    • Test each lung separately and cut into pieces to test again.
    • Press pieces to expel air and putrefactive gases and test again.
  • Inference:
    • All pieces float → respiration has taken place.
    • All pieces sink → no respiration (stillbirth).
    • Some pieces float, some sink → partial or feeble respiration.
  • Other tests for determining respiration include:
    • Fodere's test (weight changes pre/post respiration)
    • Ploucquet's test (lung weight relative to body weight)
    • Wredin's test (middle ear gelatinous substance replaced by air)

Lung edema (Option A): Causes lungs to become heavier and waterlogged → lungs sink despite respiration (false negative).

Lung collapse (Option B): Results in denser lung tissue; lungs will typically sink, not float.

Consolidation (Option D): Lung tissue filled with inflammatory exudate becomes heavier → sinks rather than floats.

choices.text: Presence of milk in the stomach
Presence of meconium in the large bowel

questions.text: An ASHA worker brings the body of a newborn to casualty saying that the child was delivered dead at home. You suspect it as a live birth and request an autopsy. All the following will confirm a live birth except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Presence of meconium in the large bowel is not a confirmatory sign of live birth.
  • In fact, absence of meconium in the large bowel may suggest live birth, except in cases like breech delivery where meconium may be present even in stillbirths.

Confirmatory signs of live birth include:

  • Presence of milk in the stomach (indicating feeding).
  • Exfoliation of skin (skin peeling due to postnatal life).
  • Closure of fetal channels (like ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale).
  • Changes in the umbilical cord.

Live birth can be excluded if:

  • Signs of maceration are present.
  • Signs of immaturity are present.
  • The child has not attained viable age (less than 7 months gestation).

Presence of milk in the stomach (Option A): Indicates the baby has fed after birth → confirms live birth.

Skin exfoliation (Option B): A sign of postnatal life → confirms live birth.

Closure of foetal channels (Option D): Physiological changes that occur after birth → confirms live birth.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of meconium in the large bowel is not a reliable sign of live birth.
  • Other clinical and pathological signs are needed to confirm if a newborn was alive at birth.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Robert's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Robert's sign is a radiological sign indicating the presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or major vessels such as the aorta.
  • It appears in cases of fetal death in utero.
  • This is the earliest sign of maceration, detectable about 12 hours after fetal death.

Foetal distress (Option A): A condition where the fetus experiences inadequate oxygen but no gas shadows inside the heart/vessels.

Postmature foetus (Option B): Refers to a fetus beyond normal gestational age; Robert's sign is unrelated.

Premature foetus (Option C): Born before term; no association with Robert's sign.

Key Takeaways:

  • Robert's sign indicates intrauterine fetal death and early maceration.
  • It is a useful radiological clue in postmortem diagnosis of fetal demise.

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a fetus born dead at 6 months. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Adipocere formation is a postmortem change involving the conversion of body fats into a waxy, greyish-white, greasy substance with a sweet rancid odor.
  • It occurs due to postmortem hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fats, usually in bodies immersed in water or damp, warm environments.
  • Foetuses under 7 months gestation do not develop adipocere, making it least likely in a 6-month stillborn fetus.

Other postmortem changes seen in dead-born fetuses:

  • Mummification: (Option A ruled out)
    • Drying and desiccation of the fetus after death in utero with scanty amniotic fluid and no air exposure.
    • It takes about 2 weeks.
  • Putrefaction:
    • Occurs when membranes rupture allowing air entry, leading to decomposition.
  • Resorption: (Option C ruled out)
    • The dead fetus may be gradually resorbed if pregnancy continues.
  • Maceration: (Option D ruled out)
    • Autolytic self-disintegration of the fetus by cellular enzymes; the most important change after intrauterine death.

Key Takeaways:

  • Adipocere formation requires conditions not typical for a fetus less than 7 months gestation.
  • Maceration is the hallmark postmortem change in intrauterine fetal death.
  • Mummification and resorption can also occur depending on circumstances.

questions.text: You are using Haase's rule for the estimation of fetal age in a pregnant woman. Which of the following parameters is used here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Haase's rule estimates the gestational age (in lunar months) of the fetus based on its crown-heel length (CHL) measured in centimeters.
  • Rule of Haase:
    • If CHL < 25 cm,
    • Age in lunar months = √(Crown heel length)
  • Morrison's rule:
    • If CHL > 25 cm,
    • Age in lunar months = Crown heel length ÷ 5

Biparietal diameter (Option A): Measurement of fetal head width, used in other age estimation methods but not Haase's rule.

Head circumference (Option B): Another fetal measurement used for growth assessment but not in Haase's rule.

Femoral length (Option D): Commonly used in fetal biometry but not part of Haase's or Morrison's rules.

Key Takeaways:

  • Haase's rule and Morrison's rule use crown-heel length for estimating fetal age in lunar months.
  • The formulas differ based on whether the crown-heel length is less or more than 25 cm.

questions.text: X-ray of a child shows a nobbing fracture. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nobbing fractures are characteristic of battered baby syndrome, a form of child abuse.
  • These fractures occur when an assailant violently shakes the child (infantile whiplash syndrome/shaken baby syndrome) or squeezes from side to side, fracturing ribs near the spine on both sides, producing a 'nobbing' appearance on X-ray.
  • Mechanism: Ribs may be levered against the transverse processes causing breakage.
  • Fractures become more visible after 1-2 weeks due to callus formation.
  • Rib fractures near the axillary line can result from anteroposterior pressure rather than side squeezing.

Munchausen syndrome (Option B):

  • Adults feign illness or self-injure to gain medical attention.
  • Munchausen syndrome by proxy involves caregivers fabricating illness in children but does not cause nobbing fractures.

Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) (Option C):

  • Sudden, unexplained death of a seemingly healthy infant, usually during sleep.
  • No fractures or physical trauma are involved.

Hyperabduction shoulder injury (Option D):

  • Injury due to extreme shoulder abduction causing nerve or bone injury but unrelated to rib fractures or nobbing appearance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nobbing fractures on X-ray strongly suggest non-accidental injury (child abuse).
  • Recognizing these signs is critical for timely intervention.

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarette burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This clinical picture is suggestive of battered baby syndrome (child abuse).
  • A classical feature of battered baby syndrome is that injuries are of different ages and at different stages of healing, reflecting repeated trauma over time.
  • Therefore, multiple injuries all at the same stage of healing is least likely in this condition.
  • Battered children suffer repetitive physical injuries caused by non-accidental violence, often inflicted by caregivers.
  • There may be neglect including nutritional and emotional deprivation.

Typical features to suspect battered baby syndrome:

  • Degree and type of injury inconsistent with history.
  • Injuries in different stages of healing.
  • Delay in seeking medical care despite serious injuries.
  • Presence of fractures, subdural hematomas, soft tissue swelling, and skin bruising.
  • Sudden unexplained death may occur.

Subdural hematoma (Option A): Common in abusive head trauma in battered children.

Periosteal shearing (Option B): Can be seen in fractures due to abusive trauma.

Soft tissue swelling (Option D): Often present due to bruising or inflammation from trauma.

Key Takeaways:

  • In battered baby syndrome, expect injuries of varied ages due to repeated abuse.
  • Presence of multiple injuries all at the same stage suggests accidental or single event trauma, which is less likely here.

choices.text: Sharing a bed with a family member
Sleeping in prone position or on the side

questions.text: A 2-month-old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents found that the baby was not breathing while asleep. You suspected sudden infant death syndrome in this child. Which of the following is not a risk factor of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sleeping on hard/firm surfaces is not associated with sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).
  • In fact, using a firm mattress without soft bedding or pillows is recommended to reduce SIDS risk.
  • Increased risk of SIDS is linked to soft bedding, pillows, blankets, stuffed toys, or old soft mattresses that may cause suffocation or overheating.
  • Also called 'cot' or 'crib' death.
  • Unexpected death of a seemingly healthy infant, usually during sleep, most commonly between 1–7 months of age.
  • Risk factors include male gender, multiple births, colder climates, and lower socioeconomic status.

Ways to reduce risk of SIDS include:

  • Avoid sharing a bed with the infant.
  • Abstain from smoking around the infant.
  • Use firm bedding and keep the sleeping area clear.
  • Ensure the infant sleeps supine (on their back).
  • Maintain a comfortable room temperature.
  • Promote breastfeeding.

Sharing a bed (Option A): Increases risk of SIDS, especially if the parent consumes alcohol or sedatives.

Sleeping prone or on side (Option C): Strongly associated with SIDS due to higher risk of regurgitation, choking, and airway instability.

Overheating (Option D): Excessive clothing, warm room temperature, or fever can cause overheating, which is a known risk factor for SIDS.

Key Takeaways:

  • A firm sleeping surface is protective, not a risk factor.
  • Bed sharing, prone sleeping, and overheating are established risk factors for SIDS.

questions.text: An unmarried mother purposefully drowned her newborn infant in the bathtub. She will be punished under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Infanticide is legally treated as murder under Section 103 of BNS (Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita).
  • In India, there is no legal distinction between infanticide and murder, unlike in some Western countries where specific laws (e.g., English Infanticide Act, 1938) provide special provisions for women affected by childbirth-related mental disturbance.
  • Section 103 BNS covers punishment for murder, applicable in this case of deliberate killing of a newborn.

Section 105 BNS (Option B): Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder, which implies lack of intent to cause death. Not applicable here due to deliberate drowning.

Section 93 BNS (Option C): Exposure and abandonment of a child under twelve years of age by parent or caregiver; does not cover deliberate killing.

Section 94 BNS (Option D): Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body, related to hiding evidence, not the act of killing itself.

Key Takeaways:

  • Intentional killing of a newborn (infanticide) is treated as murder under Indian law.
  • Unlike some other legal systems, India does not have special provisions mitigating infanticide cases.

questions.text: The following are the characteristics of caput succedaneum, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Caput succedaneum is present at birth, crosses suture lines, and is not limited to a single bone.
  • It resolves spontaneously within hours to a day and does not cause jaundice.
  • Limitation to a single bone is a feature of cephalohematoma, not caput.

questions.text: All tests are used to detect live birth, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Gettler's test is not used to detect live birth. It is a forensic test used to determine drowning as the cause of death by comparing chloride content in blood from the left and right sides of the heart. Normally, the difference between the two chambers is no more than 5 mg/100 ml.

  • In freshwater drowning: Chloride content in the left heart is lower than in the right.
  • In saltwater drowning: Chloride content in the left heart is higher than in the right.
  • Ploucquet's test, Fodere';s test, and Raygat's test are all used to detect live birth in forensic medicine.
  • Detection of live birth is important in medico-legal cases such as suspected infanticide.
  • Hydrostatic (lung floatation) tests are the most common category for live birth determination.

Ploucquet's test (Option A): Compares the weight of the lungs to the body weight - heavier lungs may suggest respiration occurred.

Fodere's test (Option B): Similar to hydrostatic test; evaluates buoyancy of lungs in water to determine if air entry occurred after birth.

Raygat's test (Option D): A variation of the lung floatation test used to determine live birth.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gettler's test = drowning detection, not live birth.
  • Live birth tests often rely on lung weight, buoyancy, and air content.
  • Understanding the purpose of each forensic test is essential for avoiding confusion in exams.

choices.text: Increase in weight of lungs in relation to body weight following respiration
Presence of air in middle ear
Presence of air in stomach following respiration
Change in shape of chest after respiration

questions.text: In case of infant deaths, Ploucquet's test is carried out to determine live birth by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ploucquet's test demonstrates establishment of respiration by assessing lung weight relative to body weight.
    • Before respiration, the lung weight is about 1/70 of body weight; after respiration, it increases to about 1/35 of body weight.
    • This weight gain is due to the expansion of lungs and blood aeration following breathing.
  • Fodere's test (Static test): Lungs weigh 30-40 g before respiration and 60-66 g after respiration.
  • Wredin's test: Identifies air in the middle ear post-respiration.
  • Chest shape change: Before respiration → flat chest, circumference smaller than abdomen; after respiration → arched or drum-shaped chest.

Fodere's test (Option B): Measures lung weight increase post-respiration (different absolute weight values from Ploucquet's test).

Presence of air in stomach (Option C): Indicates air swallowing after breathing, but not part of Ploucquet's test.

Change in shape of chest (Option D): Observational finding after respiration, not a weight-based lung test.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ploucquet's test is based on lung-to-body weight ratio.
  • It is a dynamic indicator of live birth and respiratory activity.
  • Should be interpreted along with other static and dynamic tests in forensic medicine.
